Q20: I picked up the book several semesters ago hoping to read it in my free time. At that point I found it nearly impenetrable and quickly gave up on it. However, while taking this course I began reading through it and found that it was nearly trivial.    I believe the reason for this is the lack of formalism in the text. A reader unfamiliar with the material may read an explanation given in English prose and parse it differently than the intended way (thus encountering a lot of confusion). Meanwhile, a reader who already knows where this is going (perhaps after covering analogous material in computability, foundations, and other logic books, or even by just attending class) will find the explanations clear and easy to grasp because they'll understand and interpret things within the context of intuition they've acquired.

I learned almost nothing from this textbook, every time I would look something up in it I would spend a huge amount of time trying to understand a simple concept and just end up frustrated and confused. I remember spending hours trying to understand this textbook's explanation of Cantor's diagonal argument, eventually I just googled it and in literally 5 minutes of reading and looking at the diagrams on the wikipedia page I understood it completely. I learn best when I see diagrams with a detailed explanation - 6 pages of text can be less effective than 2 paragraphs and a couple of diagrams.
